name: Andromeda
meaning_mythology: Represents the princess Andromeda in Greek mythology.
history: Andromeda is a prominent northern constellation named after the princess Andromeda in Greek mythology. According to myth, Andromeda was the daughter of King Cepheus and Queen Cassiopeia of Ethiopia. Her motherâ€™s boast about Andromeda's beauty angered the sea nymphs, leading Poseidon to send a sea monster, Cetus, to ravage the land. To appease the gods, Andromeda was chained to a rock as a sacrifice but was rescued by the hero Perseus, whom she later married.
fun_fact: Did you know Andromeda was named after a princess in Greek mythology who was chained to a rock to be eaten by a sea monster? Luckily, Perseus saved her just in time!

name: Antlia
meaning_mythology: Depicts an air pump; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Antlia, meaning "the Air Pump," is a constellation introduced in the 18th century by French astronomer Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille. Lacaille named it to honor the air pump, a recent invention at the time, reflecting the Age of Enlightenment's emphasis on science and technology. Antlia is relatively faint and does not contain any particularly bright stars.â€‹
fun_fact: This constellation represents an air pumpâ€”because apparently, 18th-century astronomers really liked naming things after scientific instruments.

name: Apus
meaning_mythology: Represents the bird of paradise; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in the 16th century.
history: Apus, derived from the Greek word for "footless," represents the bird-of-paradise, which was once believed to lack feet due to the way specimens were prepared and presented in Europe. This constellation was created by Dutch navigators Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman in the late 16th century during their explorations in the southern hemisphere. Apus is one of the 12 constellations introduced in Johann Bayer's star atlas "Uranometria" in 1603. â€‹
fun_fact: A constellation named after the bird of paradise, but ironically, you wonâ€™t find it in the skies of paradiseâ€”itâ€™s only visible in the Southern Hemisphere!

name: Aquarius
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the water bearer; associated with Ganymede in Greek mythology.
history: Aquarius, Latin for "water-bearer," is one of the oldest recognized constellations and a member of the zodiac. In Greek mythology, it is associated with Ganymede, a beautiful youth whom Zeus carried to Olympus to serve as the cupbearer to the gods. Aquarius is situated in a region of the sky often referred to as "the Sea" due to its association with other water-related constellations like Pisces and Cetus. The constellation was cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century and contains several notable stars and deep-sky objects. â€‹
fun_fact: The "Water Bearer" is actually Ganymede, the cupbearer of the gods, who was so handsome that Zeus kidnapped him and made him serve drinks on Mount Olympus.

name: Aquila
meaning_mythology: Represents the eagle; associated with Zeus's eagle in Greek mythology.
history: Aquila is a prominent constellation in Greek mythology, representing the eagle of Zeus. According to legend, this eagle carried Zeus' thunderbolts and was also responsible for abducting Ganymede, a beautiful Trojan prince, to serve as the cupbearer of the gods. The constellation contains Altair, one of the brightest stars in the sky and a part of the Summer Triangle. Aquila has been recognized since antiquity and was cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century.
fun_fact: Meet Zeusâ€™s personal delivery bird! Aquila, the eagle, carried Zeusâ€™s thunderboltsâ€”definitely not a bird youâ€™d want to mess with.

name: Ara
meaning_mythology: Depicts the altar; associated with the altar of the gods in Greek mythology.
history: Ara, meaning "The Altar" in Latin, is a southern constellation that dates back to ancient Greece. It was said to represent the altar upon which the gods swore allegiance to Zeus before his war against the Titans. Some stories also associate it with sacrificial rites in mythology. Ara is located in the Milky Way and contains several bright stars and deep-sky objects.
fun_fact: This is the altar where the Olympian gods made their battle plans before overthrowing the Titans. Talk about a legendary war table!

name: Aries
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the ram; associated with the golden fleece in Greek mythology.
history: Aries is one of the twelve zodiac constellations and is deeply tied to Greek mythology. It represents the Golden Ram, which saved Phrixus and Helle from being sacrificed. The ramâ€™s fleece later became the object of Jason and the Argonauts' legendary quest. Aries was recognized by Ptolemy and has been significant in astrology and navigation for centuries. It contains Hamal, its brightest star.
fun_fact: Aries is linked to the famous golden ram whose fleece was sought after by Jason and the Argonautsâ€”think of it as the original treasure hunt.

name: Auriga
meaning_mythology: Represents the charioteer; associated with Erichthonius of Athens in Greek mythology.
history: Auriga is a constellation linked to Erichthonius, a legendary king of Athens who was credited with inventing the four-horse chariot. It has also been associated with Hephaestus, the lame blacksmith god, and charioteers in general. Auriga contains Capella, one of the brightest stars in the night sky, and has been known since ancient times, appearing in Ptolemyâ€™s catalog.
fun_fact: A constellation of a charioteer, but no oneâ€™s quite sure who he isâ€”some say heâ€™s Erichthonius, a king of Athens who invented the four-horse chariot.

name: Bootes
meaning_mythology: Depicts the herdsman; associated with Arcas in Greek mythology.
history: BoÃ¶tes is often associated with Arcas, the son of Callisto, who was almost killed by his own father, Zeus, before being placed in the sky. Some myths also link BoÃ¶tes to a plowman or herdsman, guiding the Big Dipper (part of Ursa Major). The constellation contains Arcturus, one of the brightest stars in the sky. BoÃ¶tes has been documented since antiquity and continues to be a key feature in northern hemisphere star maps.
fun_fact: His name means 'herdsman,' but his brightest star, Arcturus, was historically believed to signal the start of harvest season. A cosmic farmerâ€™s almanac!

name: Caelum
meaning_mythology: Represents the chisel; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Caelum is one of the lesser-known constellations, introduced in the 18th century by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille, a French astronomer. It represents an engraving chisel, reflecting the Enlightenmentâ€™s focus on science and craftsmanship. Caelum is a faint constellation with no particularly bright stars, but it is home to some interesting binary star systems.
fun_fact: This constellation represents a sculptorâ€™s chiselâ€”because, apparently, stars needed a little artistic touch too.

name: Camelopardalis
meaning_mythology: Depicts the giraffe; introduced by Plancius in the 17th century.
history: Camelopardalis is a relatively modern constellation, named in the 17th century by Petrus Plancius. Its name comes from the Latin term for "giraffe," combining "camel" and "leopard" due to the animalâ€™s spotted coat and long legs. This northern constellation is relatively faint but holds several deep-sky objects.
fun_fact: Despite the fancy name, this constellation simply means 'giraffe'â€”because ancient astronomers thought it looked like a camel-leopard hybrid.

name: Cancer
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the crab; associated with Hercules' labors in Greek mythology.
history: Cancer is one of the zodiac constellations and represents the giant crab sent by Hera to attack Heracles during his battle with the Hydra. Heracles crushed the crab underfoot, but Hera honored its efforts by placing it in the sky. Though Cancer is not particularly bright, it contains the famous Beehive Cluster (M44).
fun_fact: This crab was sent by Hera to attack Hercules, but it was so tiny he just stepped on it. Hera felt bad and turned it into a constellation anyway.

name: Canes Venatici
meaning_mythology: Represents the hunting dogs; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Canes Venatici was introduced in the 17th century by Johannes Hevelius and represents the hunting dogs of BoÃ¶tes, the Herdsman. This small northern constellation contains some fascinating deep-sky objects, including the famous Whirlpool Galaxy (M51). Despite its late addition to star maps, Canes Venatici has become a notable feature of the sky.
fun_fact: These 'hunting dogs' were added in the 17th centuryâ€”probably because BoÃ¶tes, the herdsman, needed some loyal companions in the sky.

name: Canis Major
meaning_mythology: Depicts the greater dog; associated with Orion's hunting dog in Greek mythology.
history: Canis Major represents one of Orionâ€™s hunting dogs in Greek mythology. It is best known for containing Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky, sometimes called the "Dog Star." This constellation has been recognized since antiquity and is a key part of winter sky observations.
fun_fact: Home to Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky! Itâ€™s also said to be Orionâ€™s faithful hunting dog.

name: Canis Minor
meaning_mythology: Represents the lesser dog; associated with Orion's hunting dog in Greek mythology.
history: Like Canis Major, Canis Minor is also associated with Orionâ€™s hunting dogs. Though it is a small constellation, it contains Procyon, one of the brightest stars in the night sky. Canis Minor has been recognized since the time of Ptolemy and remains an important feature in celestial navigation.
fun_fact: The 'little dog' of the night sky may be small, but its star Procyon is one of the brightest in our galaxy.

name: Capricornus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the sea goat; associated with Pan in Greek mythology.
history: Capricornus is one of the oldest recognized constellations, dating back to the Sumerians around 2,000 BCE, who associated it with the god Enki, depicted as a half-goat, half-fish creature. In Greek mythology, it represents the goat Amalthea, who nursed the infant Zeus, or the goat-god Pan, who transformed himself into a sea creature to escape the monster Typhon. Capricornus is also one of the twelve zodiac constellations. â€‹
fun_fact: Ever seen a sea-goat? Me neither. But this constellation represents Pan, the goat god who jumped into the sea and turned half-fish.

name: Carina
meaning_mythology: Represents the keel of a ship; part of the former constellation Argo Navis.
history: Carina was once part of the larger constellation Argo Navis, representing the ship Argo from Greek mythology, which Jason and the Argonauts sailed in their quest for the Golden Fleece. In the 18th century, astronomer Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille divided Argo Navis into three smaller constellations: Carina (the keel), Vela (the sails), and Puppis (the stern). Carina contains Canopus, the second-brightest star in the night sky. â€‹
fun_fact: Once part of a massive ship-shaped constellation called Argo Navis, Carina is the 'keel' of the ship. Imagine sailing the stars!

name: Cassiopeia
meaning_mythology: Depicts Queen Cassiopeia in Greek mythology.
history: Cassiopeia is a prominent northern constellation representing the vain queen Cassiopeia from Greek mythology, wife of King Cepheus and mother of Andromeda. According to legend, her boast about her unrivaled beauty angered the sea nymphs, leading Poseidon to send a sea monster to punish her kingdom. Cassiopeia was placed in the sky as a constellation, depicted sitting on her throne. â€‹
fun_fact: A vain queen who bragged too much and got stuck upside down in the sky as punishment. Ouch.

name: Centaurus
meaning_mythology: Represents the centaur; associated with Chiron in Greek mythology.
history: Centaurus is a large southern constellation representing the centaur, a creature with the upper body of a human and the lower body of a horse. It is often associated with Chiron, the wise and noble centaur from Greek mythology who tutored many heroes, including Hercules and Achilles. Centaurus contains Alpha Centauri, the closest star system to Earth. â€‹
fun_fact: This constellation is home to Chiron, the kind and wise centaurâ€”basically, the galaxyâ€™s original mentor.

name: Cepheus
meaning_mythology: Depicts King Cepheus in Greek mythology.
history: Cepheus represents King Cepheus of Ethiopia in Greek mythology, husband of Cassiopeia and father of Andromeda. Placed near his wife in the sky, Cepheus is depicted as a king holding a scepter. The constellation is relatively faint but holds significance due to its mythological associations. â€‹
fun_fact: King Cepheus might not be as famous as his wife Cassiopeia or daughter Andromeda, but at least he got a constellation out of it!

name: Cetus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the whale or sea monster; associated with the sea monster sent to devour Andromeda in Greek mythology.
history: Cetus represents the sea monster sent by Poseidon to ravage the land of King Cepheus after his wife, Cassiopeia, boasted about her beauty. The creature was defeated by Perseus when he rescued Andromeda. Cetus is one of the largest constellations in the sky and has been known since antiquity. â€‹
fun_fact: This sea monster was supposed to eat Andromeda, but Perseus turned it to stone with Medusaâ€™s head. Sorry, Cetus.

name: Chamaeleon
meaning_mythology: Represents the chameleon; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in the 16th century.
history: Chamaeleon is a small constellation introduced in the late 16th century by Dutch navigators Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman. It represents the chameleon, a lizard known for its ability to change color. Chamaeleon is located in the southern sky and is one of the 12 constellations introduced by Keyser and de Houtman. â€‹
fun_fact: This tiny Southern Hemisphere constellation is named after the color-changing lizard, but sadly, the stars donâ€™t change color.

name: Circinus
meaning_mythology: Depicts the compass (drafting tool); introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Circinus, meaning "the compass" in Latin, was introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents the drawing tool used in geometry and navigation. Circinus is a small, faint constellation located in the southern hemisphere near Centaurus and Lupus. â€‹
fun_fact: Representing a drafting compass, this constellation is the universeâ€™s way of saying, 'Math is everywhere!'

name: Columba
meaning_mythology: Represents the dove; introduced by Plancius in the 16th century.
history: Columba was introduced by Dutch astronomer Petrus Plancius in the late 16th century. It represents the dove and is sometimes associated with the dove that informed Noah of receding floodwaters in biblical tradition. Columba is located near Canis Major in the southern sky. â€‹
fun_fact: The 'Dove' constellation was added in the 1500sâ€”possibly to represent Noahâ€™s dove from the biblical flood story.

name: Coma Berenices
meaning_mythology: Depicts Berenice's Hair; associated with Queen Berenice II of Egypt.
history: Coma Berenices represents the hair of Queen Berenice II of Egypt. According to legend, she sacrificed her long hair to the gods for her husband's safe return from war. The constellation was recognized by the Greeks as a distinct grouping and was later included in star catalogs. Coma Berenices is notable for containing a rich star cluster. â€‹
fun_fact: Named after a real queen, Berenice II, who sacrificed her hair for the godsâ€”her locks were so glorious, they became a constellation!

name: Corona Australis
meaning_mythology: Represents the southern crown; associated with a wreath or crown in Greek mythology.
history: Corona Australis, meaning "the southern crown," is a small constellation located in the southern hemisphere. It was first cataloged by the Greek astronomer Ptolemy in the 2nd century. The constellation is sometimes associated with the myth of Dionysus, representing the crown the god placed in the sky after freeing his mother Semele from the underworld. â€‹
fun_fact: A small, dim constellation known as the 'Southern Crown'â€”basically a royal tiara in the sky.

name: Corona Borealis
meaning_mythology: Depicts the northern crown; associated with the crown given to Ariadne by Dionysus in Greek mythology.
history: Corona Borealis, meaning "the northern crown," is a small constellation in the northern hemisphere. In Greek mythology, it represents the crown given by Dionysus to Ariadne upon their marriage. The constellation is notable for its distinctive semicircular arc of stars. â€‹
fun_fact: The 'Northern Crown' was a wedding gift from the god Dionysus to Ariadne. Talk about celestial jewelry!

name: Corvus
meaning_mythology: Represents the crow; associated with Apollo's sacred bird in Greek mythology.
history: Corvus is a small constellation representing a crow or raven in Greek mythology. It is linked to the god Apollo, who sent a crow to fetch water. The crow became distracted by a fig tree and returned late, bringing a water snake (Hydra) as an excuse. Apollo, angered by the deception, cast the crow, the cup (Crater), and the snake (Hydra) into the sky.
fun_fact: This crow was Apolloâ€™s messenger, but he got caught slacking off and was thrown into the sky as punishment.

name: Crater
meaning_mythology: Depicts the cup; associated with the cup of Apollo in Greek mythology.
history: Crater represents the cup of Apollo in Greek mythology. According to legend, it was carried by the crow Corvus, but due to the crow's failure to complete its task, Apollo placed it in the sky along with Corvus and Hydra as punishment.
fun_fact: A celestial cup! It was said to belong to Apollo, though itâ€™s unclear whether it was for ambrosia or something stronger.

name: Crux
meaning_mythology: Represents the Southern Cross; a significant navigational symbol in the southern hemisphere.
first_appearance: Recognized as a distinct constellation in the 16th century.
history: Crux is a small but significant southern constellation representing a cross. Though it was visible to ancient Greeks, it later became primarily associated with the Age of Exploration, helping sailors navigate. Crux contains Acrux, one of the brightest stars in the sky, and is deeply significant to cultures in the Southern Hemisphere.Cygnus represents a swan and is linked to multiple Greek myths. One legend associates it with Orpheus, who was transformed into a swan upon his death and placed in the sky next to Lyra. Another story ties it to Zeus, who took the form of a swan to seduce Leda. It contains Deneb, part of the Summer Triangle.
fun_fact: The Southern Cross is the smallest constellation but one of the most famous in the Southern Hemisphereâ€”it's even on some national flags!

name: Cygnus
meaning_mythology: Depicts the swan; associated with various myths, including Zeus transforming into a swan.
history: Cygnus represents a swan and is linked to multiple Greek myths. One legend associates it with Orpheus, who was transformed into a swan upon his death and placed in the sky next to Lyra. Another story ties it to Zeus, who took the form of a swan to seduce Leda. It contains Deneb, part of the Summer Triangle.
fun_fact: The Swan, but really Zeus in disguiseâ€”he had a habit of turning into birds to woo mortal women!

name: Delphinus
meaning_mythology: Represents the dolphin; linked to the Greek myth of Arion and the dolphin.
history: Delphinus represents a dolphin and is connected to the myth of Poseidon, who sent a dolphin to retrieve the nymph Amphitrite, whom he wished to marry. As a reward, Poseidon placed the dolphin among the stars.
fun_fact: A dolphin that supposedly saved a Greek poet from drowning! Maybe the first-ever lifeguard!

name: Dorado
meaning_mythology: Depicts the dolphinfish; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Dorado is a southern constellation introduced in the late 16th century by Dutch explorers. It represents the dorado fish (or mahi-mahi) and is best known for containing the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way.
fun_fact: Named after the dolphinfish, not an actual dolphin. But itâ€™s home to the Large Magellanic Cloud, a mini-galaxy orbiting the Milky Way!

name: Draco
meaning_mythology: Represents the dragon; associated with the dragon Ladon in Greek mythology.
history: Draco is one of the largest constellations and represents a dragon from Greek mythology. It is associated with Ladon, the dragon that guarded the golden apples in the Garden of the Hesperides. Hercules defeated the dragon, and it was placed in the sky as a reward.
fun_fact: A dragon wrapped around the North Pole, said to be slain by Hercules in one of his famous labors!

name: Equuleus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the little horse or foal; associated with the mythological horse Celeris.
history: Equuleus is the second smallest constellation and represents a foal or small horse. It is linked to Hipparchus, a winged horse related to Pegasus, and was cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century.
fun_fact: A baby horse in the sky! Itâ€™s said to be the less-famous brother of Pegasus.

name: Eridanus
meaning_mythology: Represents the river; associated with the river Po in Greek mythology.
history: Eridanus is one of the longest constellations, representing a great celestial river. In Greek mythology, it is associated with the story of Phaethon, the son of Helios, who attempted to drive his fatherâ€™s chariot of the sun. Unable to control the fiery horses, Phaethon lost control, scorching parts of the Earth before Zeus struck him down with a thunderbolt. His lifeless body fell into a river, believed to be the Eridanus River, and was later placed in the sky as a warning. The constellation contains Achernar, one of the brightest stars in the night sky.
fun_fact: A river of stars, said to be the place where Phaethon crashed after failing to drive the sun chariot!

name: Fornax
meaning_mythology: Depicts the furnace; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Fornax is a modern constellation, introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents a chemical furnace, reflecting the scientific advancements of the Enlightenment. Fornax does not contain many bright stars but is home to the Fornax Galaxy Cluster, one of the closest large clusters of galaxies to Earth.

name: Gemini
meaning_mythology: Represents the twins Castor and Pollux in Greek mythology.
history: Gemini is one of the zodiac constellations, representing the twins Castor and Pollux from Greek mythology. The twins were sons of Zeus and Leda, and upon their death, Zeus placed them in the sky. The constellation is known for its two bright stars, Castor and Pollux.
fun_fact: The famous twins, Castor and Pollux, so inseparable that Zeus turned them into a constellation so theyâ€™d never be apart!

name: Grus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the crane; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Grus, meaning "The Crane", is a southern constellation first introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century. The crane was considered a symbol of longevity and vigilance in many ancient cultures. Grus was originally part of Piscis Austrinus (The Southern Fish) but was later designated as a separate constellation.
fun_fact: A crane in the skyâ€”one of many animals added to the stars by Dutch explorers in the 1500s!

name: Hercules
meaning_mythology: Represents the hero Hercules in Greek mythology.
history: Hercules is one of the largest constellations in the northern sky, depicting the legendary Greek hero Heracles (Hercules). It is often shown as a kneeling figure, symbolizing his great strength. The constellation is home to the Hercules Globular Cluster (M13), one of the brightest and most famous globular clusters visible from Earth.
fun_fact: Named after the strongest hero of all time! His constellation even contains the Hercules Cluster, one of the oldest star groups ever!

name: Horologium
meaning_mythology: Depicts the clock; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Horologium is another modern constellation, named by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents a pendulum clock, an invention that revolutionized timekeeping and navigation. While it lacks bright stars, it contains several galaxies.

name: Hydra
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the water serpent; associated with the Lernaean Hydra in Greek mythology.
history: Hydra is the largest constellation in the sky, spanning over 100 degrees of the celestial sphere. In Greek mythology, it represents the Lernaean Hydra, a monstrous multi-headed serpent slain by Hercules as one of his Twelve Labors. The Hydra was said to be nearly impossible to kill because every time Hercules cut off one of its heads, two more would grow in its place. With the help of his nephew Iolaus, he cauterized the wounds after severing each head, preventing regeneration. As a reward, Zeus placed the Hydra in the sky. Hydra also features in the myth of Corvus and Crater, where Apollo punished the crow by placing it alongside the serpent. The constellation contains Alphard, its brightest star.
fun_fact: The longest constellation in the sky, but unlike the myth, this serpent only has one head!

name: Hydrus
meaning_mythology: Represents the male water snake; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Hydrus is a small southern constellation, created by Dutch explorers Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman in the late 16th century during their voyages. Unlike its larger counterpart, Hydra, Hydrus does not have a mythological origin. Instead, it was named after the freshwater eels and sea serpents encountered by sailors in the Southern Hemisphere. Despite its small size, Hydrus is notable for containing Beta Hydri, one of the closest Sun-like stars to Earth.
fun_fact: The longest constellation in the sky, but unlike the myth, this serpent only has one head!

name: Indus
meaning_mythology: Depicts the Indian; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Indus is a southern constellation that was introduced by Petrus Plancius in the late 16th century, based on observations made by Dutch explorers. Unlike the classical constellations of Greek mythology, Indus was named after the indigenous peoples of the East Indies, Africa, and the Americas, whom European explorers encountered during their voyages. The constellation does not contain any bright stars but serves as an important navigational marker in the southern hemisphere.

name: Lacerta
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the lizard; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Lacerta, meaning "the Lizard", is another relatively modern constellation, introduced in 1687 by Johannes Hevelius. It is one of the lesser-known constellations, filling a previously uncharted area of the sky between Andromeda and Cygnus. Due to its location in a crowded region of the Milky Way, Lacerta contains several notable deep-sky objects, including open star clusters and nebulae. However, it does not have strong mythological connections like many other constellations.

name: Leo
meaning_mythology: Represents the lion; associated with the Nemean lion in Greek mythology.
history: Leo is one of the most well-known zodiac constellations and has been recognized since ancient times. In Greek mythology, it represents the Nemean Lion, a massive and invulnerable beast that terrorized the region of Nemea. As part of his Twelve Labors, Hercules was tasked with slaying the lion. Upon realizing that its hide was impervious to weapons, he strangled the beast with his bare hands. Zeus later placed the lion in the sky as a constellation to honor Herculesâ€™ feat. The constellationâ€™s brightest star, Regulus, is often called the "heart of the lion." Leo has also been associated with the Sphinx of ancient Egypt and has held significance in Babylonian and Persian cultures.
fun_fact: The Nemean Lion defeated by Herculesâ€”its skin was indestructible, which is why he had to strangle it!

name: Leo Minor
meaning_mythology: Depicts the smaller lion; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Leo Minor is a relatively modern constellation, first introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687. Unlike many ancient constellations, Leo Minor does not have a strong mythological background. Hevelius placed it between the larger Leo and Ursa Major, filling a previously uncharted space in the celestial sphere. It represents a small lion and was added to complement Leo. Although Leo Minor lacks particularly bright stars, it contains several interesting galaxies.

name: Lepus
meaning_mythology: Represents the hare; located under the feet of Orion.
history: Lepus is an ancient constellation located directly beneath Orion, the great hunter, and near Canis Major, one of Orionâ€™s hunting dogs. It is often depicted as the prey of Orion, who is forever chasing it across the night sky. While the origins of Lepus are uncertain, the constellation has been recognized since at least the time of Ptolemy, who included it in his star catalog in the 2nd century. Some myths suggest that Lepus represents the swift-footed hare that was a gift to the gods, while others associate it with rabbits of the moon, a common theme in many ancient cultures, including Chinese and Native American folklore.
fun_fact: A rabbit forever hiding under Orionâ€™s feetâ€”one of the only celestial bunnies out there!

name: Libra
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the scales; associated with balance and justice.
history: Libra is one of the zodiac constellations and is unique in that it is the only zodiac sign that represents an inanimate object rather than a living being. The ancient Babylonians originally saw it as part of Scorpius, representing the Scorpionâ€™s claws. The Romans later redefined it as a separate constellation, associating it with the scales of justice held by Astraea, the goddess of justice (often linked with Virgo). Libra is home to Zubenelgenubi and Zubeneschamali, two bright stars whose names mean "southern claw" and "northern claw," remnants of its earlier connection to Scorpius.
fun_fact: The scales of justice, and the only zodiac sign that isnâ€™t a person or an animal!

name: Lupus
meaning_mythology: Depicts the wolf; associated with various myths, including the wolf slain by Hercules.
history: Lupus is an ancient constellation, first cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century, though it was not originally given a specific identity. The Greeks and Romans often referred to it as "the beast", representing a creature slain by the nearby Centaurus, possibly as a sacrificial offering. While later interpretations identified it as a wolf, ancient cultures saw it as a variety of animals, including a leopard or a generic wild beast.

name: Lynx
meaning_mythology: Represents the lynx; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Lynx is a modern constellation, introduced in the 17th century by Johannes Hevelius. It was named due to its faint stars, which Hevelius said required the eyesight of a lynx to see. Unlike many constellations, Lynx does not have a strong mythological connection but was created to fill an empty space between Ursa Major and Auriga. It contains Lynx-1, one of the oldest known exoplanetary systems.

name: Lyra
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the lyre; associated with the instrument of Orpheus in Greek mythology.
history: Lyra is a small but significant constellation linked to Orpheus, the legendary musician of Greek mythology. It represents the lyre (a stringed musical instrument) given to Orpheus by Apollo. Orpheus played the lyre so beautifully that he could charm animals, trees, and even the gods. After his tragic death, Zeus placed the lyre in the sky. Vega, the constellationâ€™s brightest star, is one of the most luminous stars visible from Earth and is part of the Summer Triangle.

name: Mensa
meaning_mythology: Depicts Table Mountain; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Mensa is a southern constellation named by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents Table Mountain (Tafelberg) in South Africa, which Lacaille observed while mapping the stars of the Southern Hemisphere. Unlike many constellations with mythological origins, Mensa reflects scientific exploration. It is notable for containing part of the Large Magellanic Cloud, a neighboring galaxy to the Milky Way.

name: Microscopium
meaning_mythology: Represents the microscope; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Microscopium is a modern constellation, introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century during the Age of Enlightenment. Named after the microscope, it symbolizes the scientific advancements of the time. While it is a faint constellation with no particularly bright stars, it reflects humanityâ€™s pursuit of knowledge.

name: Monoceros
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the unicorn; introduced by Plancius in the 17th century.
history: Monoceros is a relatively modern constellation, first recorded in the 17th century by the Dutch astronomer Petrus Plancius. It represents a unicorn, a mythical creature found in various cultural traditions. The constellation is located near Orion, Canis Major, and Canis Minor, blending into a region rich with celestial objects. It contains the Rosette Nebula and the Christmas Tree Cluster, making it an interesting area for astronomers.

name: Musca
meaning_mythology: Depicts the fly; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Musca is a southern constellation introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century. It was originally called "Apis" (the Bee) but was later renamed Musca (the Fly). It is one of the few constellations named after an insect. Though small, it is important in the southern hemisphereâ€™s celestial mapping.

name: Norma
meaning_mythology: Represents the carpenter's square; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Norma is another modern constellation, named by Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents a carpenterâ€™s square or drafting tool, reflecting the Age of Enlightenmentâ€™s emphasis on engineering and science. Norma is home to several interesting binary star systems and deep-sky objects.

name: Octans
meaning_mythology: Represents the octant, a navigational instrument.
history: Octans is a southern constellation, introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents the octant, a navigation instrument that was a precursor to the modern sextant. Octans is notable because it contains Sigma Octantis, the southern pole star, although it is much dimmer than the North Star (Polaris).

name: Ophiuchus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the serpent-bearer; associated with Asclepius, the healer in Greek mythology.
history: Ophiuchus is one of the largest constellations and is often called the "13th zodiac sign", though it is not traditionally included in astrology. It represents Asclepius, the Greek god of medicine, who was said to have the ability to bring the dead back to life. The constellation is depicted as a man holding a serpent, symbolizing wisdom and healing. The serpent itself is represented by the adjacent Serpens constellation. Ophiuchus is home to several globular clusters and Barnardâ€™s Star, one of the closest stars to Earth.
fun_fact: The 'Serpent Bearer', a legendary healer. Some people call him the forgotten zodiac sign!

name: Orion
meaning_mythology: Represents the hunter; a prominent figure in Greek mythology.
history: Orion is one of the most famous constellations, easily recognizable by its three-star belt. In Greek mythology, Orion was a mighty hunter, sometimes described as the son of Poseidon. He boasted that he could kill all the wild animals on Earth, angering Artemis or Gaia, who sent a giant scorpion (Scorpius) to slay him. After his death, Zeus placed him in the sky, where he eternally hunts near his dogs, Canis Major and Canis Minor. Orion contains several bright stars, including Betelgeuse (a red supergiant) and Rigel (a blue supergiant), as well as the Orion Nebula (M42), one of the most studied celestial objects.
fun_fact: One of the most famous constellations! A hunter who was either killed by a scorpion or accidentally shot by Artemisâ€”either way, he ended up in the stars!

name: Pavo
meaning_mythology: Depicts the peacock; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Pavo is a southern constellation, first introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century. The name means "peacock" in Latin, and it was likely inspired by exotic peafowls encountered during voyages to the East Indies. It does not have a mythological connection but serves as part of the celestial menagerie of animals introduced in that era. Pavo is home to NGC 6752, one of the brightest globular clusters in the sky.

name: Pegasus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the winged horse in Greek mythology.
history: Pegasus is a large mythological constellation named after the winged horse of Greek legend. According to myth, Pegasus sprang from the blood of Medusa when Perseus beheaded her. The horse later helped the hero Bellerophon defeat the Chimera. However, when Bellerophon attempted to ride Pegasus to Olympus, Zeus sent a gadfly to sting the horse, causing Bellerophon to fall back to Earth. Pegasus was then placed among the stars. The constellation is home to the Great Square of Pegasus, a prominent asterism, and 51 Pegasi, the first Sun-like star discovered to host an exoplanet
fun_fact: The famous flying horse, born when Perseus cut off Medusaâ€™s head!

name: Perseus
meaning_mythology: Represents the hero Perseus in Greek mythology.
history: Perseus is a constellation named after the legendary Greek hero Perseus, who slayed Medusa and rescued Andromeda. He is often depicted holding Medusaâ€™s severed head, with the bright star Algol representing her "blinking eye". Algol is actually one of the first discovered eclipsing binary stars, which causes its brightness to vary over time. The Perseus constellation is home to the Perseus Cluster and the famous Perseid meteor shower, which originates from debris left by Comet Swift-Tuttle.

name: Phoenix
meaning_mythology: Depicts the mythical phoenix; introduced by Dutch explorers in the late 16th century.
history: Phoenix is a southern constellation introduced in the 16th century by Dutch navigators. It is named after the mythical phoenix, a bird that was said to be reborn from its ashes every 500 years. While it does not have direct ties to Greek mythology, the concept of the phoenix appears in Egyptian, Persian, and Chinese traditions. The constellation contains Ankaa, a bright star whose name means "phoenix" in Arabic.

name: Pisces
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the fish; associated with Aphrodite and Eros in Greek mythology.
history: Pisces is a zodiac constellation with roots in Babylonian and Greek mythology. In Greek stories, Pisces represents Aphrodite (Venus) and her son Eros (Cupid), who transformed into fish to escape the monster Typhon. They tied themselves together with a rope so they wouldnâ€™t be separated, which is why the constellation is often depicted as two fish connected by a cord. Pisces is home to the Vernal Equinox, the point where the Sun crosses the celestial equator, marking the beginning of spring.
fun_fact: The fish of the zodiac, representing Aphrodite and Eros, who turned into fish to escape a monster!

name: Pictor
meaning_mythology: Represents the painter's easel; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Pictor is one of the small, modern constellations introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents an artistâ€™s easel, reflecting the Enlightenmentâ€™s focus on science and the arts. Though relatively faint, Pictor is notable for hosting Pictor A, a powerful radio galaxy with a massive black hole.

name: Piscis Austrinus
meaning_mythology: Represents the southern fish; associated with the Great Fish in Greek mythology.
history: Piscis Austrinus is an ancient constellation representing a solitary fish. In Greek mythology, it is sometimes linked to the fish that swallowed the water from the deluge, or the parent of the two fish in Pisces. The constellation contains Fomalhaut, one of the brightest stars in the sky, sometimes called "the lonely star" because it is in an otherwise empty region of space.

name: Puppis
meaning_mythology: Depicts the stern of a ship; part of the former constellation Argo Navis.
history: Puppis was originally part of Argo Navis, the massive mythological ship that carried Jason and the Argonauts. In the 18th century, Lacaille divided Argo Navis into three smaller constellations: Carina (the keel), Vela (the sails), and Puppis (the stern). Puppis contains several bright open star clusters, including M46, M47, and the famous Vela Supernova Remnant.

name: Pyxis
meaning_mythology: Represents the mariner's compass; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Pyxis is another modern constellation introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents a marinerâ€™s compass, reflecting the importance of navigation during the Age of Exploration. Pyxis is located near Puppis, leading some to suggest it was originally part of Argo Navis, symbolizing the shipâ€™s compass. One of its most famous stars is T Pyxidis, a recurrent nova system.

name: Reticulum
meaning_mythology: Depicts the reticle, a small net; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Reticulum is a small, modern constellation introduced by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents a reticle, the crosshairs in a telescopeâ€™s eyepiece, used for astronomical measurements. Unlike the ancient mythological constellations, Reticulum reflects the scientific advancements of the Enlightenment. Despite its small size, it is home to NGC 1559, a barred spiral galaxy.

name: Sagitta
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the arrow; associated with various myths, including Hercules' arrow.
history: Sagitta, Latin for "arrow", is one of the smallest and oldest constellations, cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century. Despite its size, it was recognized by the ancient Greeks and Romans, who saw it as an arrow shot by Hercules to slay the Stymphalian birds (one of his Twelve Labors). Some myths also associate it with the arrow of Eros (Cupid) or Apolloâ€™s arrow, which struck the Cyclops.

name: Sagittarius
meaning_mythology: Represents the archer; associated with the centaur Chiron in Greek mythology.
history: Sagittarius is one of the twelve zodiac constellations, linked to Chiron, the wise centaur from Greek mythology. Chiron was known as a teacher of heroes, including Achilles and Hercules. He was placed in the sky as a centaur drawing a bow, symbolizing wisdom and skill in archery. Sagittarius is one of the richest constellations in deep-sky objects because it lies in the direction of the Milky Wayâ€™s center. It contains the Lagoon Nebula (M8), Trifid Nebula (M20), and the supermassive black hole at the galaxyâ€™s core, Sagittarius A*.
fun_fact: The archer centaur, sometimes linked to Chiron, the smartest and kindest of all centaurs!

name: Scorpius
meaning_mythology: Depicts the scorpion; associated with the scorpion that killed Orion in Greek mythology.
history: Scorpius is one of the most ancient zodiac constellations, known to the Sumerians, Babylonians, and Greeks. In Greek mythology, it represents the scorpion that killed Orion after he boasted that he could slay every animal on Earth. To honor the scorpion, Zeus placed it in the sky opposite Orion, ensuring that the two would never appear in the sky at the same time. Antares, a massive red supergiant, is the brightest star in Scorpius. The constellation also contains numerous star clusters, including M4 and the Butterfly Cluster (M6).
fun_fact: The scorpion that killed Orion! They were put on opposite sides of the sky so Orion could never be stung again!

name: Sculptor
meaning_mythology: Represents the sculptor's workshop; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Sculptor is a modern constellation, introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century. Originally named "Apparatus Sculptoris", it represented an artistâ€™s workshop. It was later shortened to Sculptor. This constellation is best known for containing the Sculptor Galaxy (NGC 253), one of the closest spiral galaxies to Earth.

name: Scutum
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the shield; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Scutum, meaning "shield" in Latin, is one of the few constellations named after a historical figure rather than mythology. It was introduced in 1684 by Johannes Hevelius to honor King John III Sobieski of Poland, who defeated the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Vienna in 1683. Scutum is a small constellation but is home to the Wild Duck Cluster (M11), one of the richest open star clusters.

name: Serpens Caput
meaning_mythology: Represents the serpent; unique as it is split into two parts: Serpens Caput and Serpens Cauda.
history: Serpens is unique among constellations because it is split into two parts: Serpens Caput (the Serpentâ€™s Head) and Serpens Cauda (the Serpentâ€™s Tail), which are separated by Ophiuchus, the Serpent Bearer. It represents the serpent held by Asclepius, the Greek god of medicine, symbolizing healing and renewal. This association remains today in the Rod of Asclepius, a medical symbol. Serpens is home to the Eagle Nebula (M16) and the famous Pillars of Creation.

name: Serpens Cauda
meaning_mythology: Represents the serpent; unique as it is split into two parts: Serpens Caput and Serpens Cauda.
history: Serpens is unique among constellations because it is split into two parts: Serpens Caput (the Serpentâ€™s Head) and Serpens Cauda (the Serpentâ€™s Tail), which are separated by Ophiuchus, the Serpent Bearer. It represents the serpent held by Asclepius, the Greek god of medicine, symbolizing healing and renewal. This association remains today in the Rod of Asclepius, a medical symbol. Serpens is home to the Eagle Nebula (M16) and the famous Pillars of Creation.

name: Sextans
meaning_mythology: Depicts the sextant, a navigational instrument; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Sextans is another scientific constellation introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century. It represents the sextant, a tool used for celestial navigation. Sextans is relatively faint but contains several galaxies, including the Sextans Dwarf Galaxy, a satellite of the Milky Way.

name: Taurus
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the bull; associated with Zeus transforming into a bull in Greek mythology.
history: Taurus is one of the most famous zodiac constellations, known since ancient times. It represents the bull form of Zeus, who abducted Europa, a Phoenician princess. Taurus is also associated with the Cretan Bull and the bull of the Epic of Gilgamesh. It is home to the bright star Aldebaran, the Hyades star cluster, and the famous Pleiades (Seven Sisters) cluster. The Taurid meteor shower originates from this constellation.

name: Telescopium
meaning_mythology: Represents the telescope; introduced by Lacaille in the 18th century.
history: Telescopium is a southern constellation, created by Lacaille in the 18th century, representing the invention of the telescope. It does not have any particularly bright stars but symbolizes humanityâ€™s advances in astronomy and science.

name: Triangulum
meaning_mythology: Depicts the triangle; associated with the Nile Delta in Egyptian mythology.
history: Triangulum is one of the smallest and oldest constellations, first cataloged by Ptolemy in the 2nd century. The ancient Babylonians saw it as a plow, while the Greeks associated it with the Nile Delta or Sicily, an island shaped like a triangle. It is home to M33 (the Triangulum Galaxy), the third-largest galaxy in the Local Group after the Milky Way and Andromeda.

name: Triangulum Australe
meaning_mythology: Represents the southern triangle; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in the 16th century.
history: Triangulum Australe is the southern counterpart of Triangulum, created in the 16th century by Dutch explorers. Unlike its northern namesake, it has no ancient mythology. The constellation contains Atria, one of the brightest stars in the Southern Hemisphere, and lies near the Coalsack Nebula.

name: Tucana
meaning_mythology: Depicts the toucan; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in the 16th century.
history: Tucana is a southern constellation, introduced by Dutch navigators Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman in the 16th century. It represents the tropical bird, the toucan, which the explorers encountered on their voyages. Tucana is famous for hosting the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC), a dwarf galaxy orbiting the Milky Way.

name: Ursa Major
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the great bear; associated with Callisto in Greek mythology.
history: Ursa Major is one of the most famous constellations, visible in the Northern Hemisphere year-round. It is deeply rooted in Greek mythology, representing Callisto, a nymph transformed into a bear by Zeus. Her son Arcas nearly killed her while hunting, so Zeus placed them both in the sky as Ursa Major and Ursa Minor. The Big Dipper (or Plough) is an asterism within Ursa Major, used for navigation, as it points to Polaris (the North Star).
fun_fact: Home of the Big Dipper! It represents the Great Bear, found in myths all around the world.

name: Ursa Minor
meaning_mythology: Represents the little bear; associated with Arcas in Greek mythology.
history: Ursa Minor is closely tied to Ursa Major, representing Arcas, the son of Callisto. This constellation is notable because it contains Polaris, the North Star, which has been used for navigation for centuries. In Greek mythology, Zeus placed Arcas in the sky after nearly being killed by his mother, Callisto, who had been transformed into a bear. The Little Dipper asterism is part of Ursa Minor.

name: Vela
meaning_mythology: Depicts the sails of a ship; part of the former constellation Argo Navis.
history: Vela was originally part of Argo Navis, the ship of Jason and the Argonauts, but was divided into three separate constellations by Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille in the 18th century: Carina (the Keel), Puppis (the Stern), and Vela (the Sails). The constellation contains the Vela Supernova Remnant, one of the most studied supernova remnants.

name: Virgo
meaning_mythology: Symbolizes the maiden; associated with various goddesses, including Demeter and Astraea.
history: Virgo is one of the largest zodiac constellations and represents Astraea, the Greek goddess of justice and purity, or Demeter, the goddess of the harvest. It has been depicted as a maiden holding a sheaf of wheat, symbolizing fertility and agriculture. Virgo is home to Spica, one of the brightest stars in the sky, and the Virgo Cluster of galaxies, one of the largest-known galaxy clusters.
fun_fact: The largest zodiac constellation, often linked to Persephone, the goddess of spring!

name: Volans
meaning_mythology: Represents the flying fish; introduced by Keyser & de Houtman in the 16th century.
history: Volans is a southern constellation, introduced in the 16th century by Dutch navigators. It represents the flying fish, a species known for gliding over the oceanâ€™s surface. The constellation is notable for containing several distant galaxies and star clusters.

name: Vulpecula
meaning_mythology: Represents the little fox; introduced by Hevelius in the 17th century.
history: Vulpecula is a faint northern constellation, introduced by Johannes Hevelius in the 17th century. Originally named Vulpecula et Anser (The Little Fox and the Goose), it was later shortened to Vulpecula. Although it lacks bright stars, it contains the Dumbbell Nebula (M27), a famous planetary nebula.
